The decorative floodgates and landscaping will enhance the aesthetic quality of the park.

chunks.text: Good afternoon. I'd like to welcome everybody to the May 14 Planet zone commission meeting. City of Davenport, if anybody has a cell phone, you have it on. I'd appreciate if you turned it off. We will start with our public hearing tonight. Commissioner Eickleberry, could you please redroll. Dunlop. Here. Eifkelberry. Here. Hepner. Here. Johnson. Here. A Tallman is excused. Ingram? Present. Manas is excused. Garrington. Schilling. Here. Thomas. Here. Schneider. Here. We have a quorum. Thank you, Commissioner Echelberry. We have one item of new business and public hearing is case row 240. Three is the request of Damports Community School District to vacate West Fifth street between Cedar and Howell street in the third ward. Matt, next one, Laura. All right, thank you. So the request is coming from the Davenport Community School District. It is to vacate Fifth street. So between Cedar street and Howell. So just to the north side you have smart middle school. And then the southern half is the former Monroe elementary school, which was demolished earlier. So the purpose is really to facilitate the redevelopment of smart intermediate. So, Fifth street currently, as it sits today, it allows for two way traffic, both east and west, and it has head in parking on both sides of the street. And it functions more so as like a parking lot for the schools rather than maybe like your standard street parking might. And the subject area, it's just under an acre. So smart middle School has been working with a team of developers to generate a concept plan for the redevelopment and how the site might facilitate. So they have explored options to preserve Fifth street. However, that has led to some challenges, being the significant increase in building height that would be required so that zoning district only has a building height of 35ft. So having less land to span across would result in additional floors. insights.observation: The Davenport Community School District is planning to vacate Fifth street between Cedar and Howell streets to redevelop Smart Middle School.
The planning involves demolishing most of the existing Smart Middle School but retaining the gym and adding new facilities on the site.
The redevelopment aims to relocate athletic fields, basketball courts, and improve the site's parking lot and design.
Concerns about student safety have been raised if Fifth street remains open, as it would require students to cross the street throughout the day.
City staff are considering the impacts on existing traffic and the neighborhood due to the redevelopment plans.
A neighborhood meeting was held for community input, but attendance was low, and only one phone call was received opposing general development.

And the very bottom portion of the plan is a house model for education. So it's a three story building. There's two houses per grade level. Each house is sort of its own self contained unit. And what that does is it lets us take a big population of students, bring it into a smaller scale, so there's a lot more interaction between student teacher. They know with having had two buildings across the street from each other, site logistics are a problem. So access into the campus was a big thing. So all of the site plan is arranged so that traffic gets off of the streets. So parking lots have drop off lanes to the bottom, to the center, and then at the top is a small bus loop. chunks.text: Good evening. I'd like to welcome everybody to tonight's plan and zone meeting. Tuesday, April 2. We will start with our public hearing agenda. Roll call, please, Commissioner Talman. Thank you, Mister Chairman. Dunlop? Here. Michael Berry? Here. Heppner? Here. Johnson? Here. Tolman? Here. Ingram? Present. Maintenance is excused. Garrington? Here. Shilling. Here. Schneider's excuse. We have a quorum, mister chairman. Thank you, Commissioner Tallman. Case our public hearing agenda. First item and only item. Case ord 240. Two. Request of the city of Davort to amend section 17.08 of the zoning ordinance regarding billboard regulations. Laura? Thank you. So I want to kind of explain why we're here in the first place. So, back in December of December 13, 2023, city council put a moratorium on billboards into effect. The purpose of that moratorium was to give staff time to evaluate its current billboard code and make any necessary changes as appropriate. So in the moratorium, there's to be no new construction of billboards that expires June 13 of 2024. So, map on the right is showing the billboard locations that we have. Currently there are 73 throughout the city right now. The circles around them are 1500ft. We measure along the street, but it was easier to demonstrate the area via the radial. So I wanted to go over the current billboard regulations with you so you know where we're at right now, and then kind of discuss future, what the problems we've heard are and things like that. So currently, billboards is written into our code as a principal use. It's not a sign, so it is only allowed in four zoning districts currently. So we have c two, c three, I one and I two. Being that it is principal use, we do have principal use standards associated with them. So there's some locational restrictions. So they're prohibited from being visible from the interstates. They're prohibited on local Davenport historic registry of Places. If the sign is less than 300 sqft, it must be a minimum of 100ft from any residential district, and if the sign is over 300 sqft, then it must be a minimum of 150ft from any residential district. So to continue onto that, the maximum sign area for a billboard is 672 sqft. There is some additional allowance for extension areas. That's when they exceed the normal frame of a billboard. So it could be things that have a shape like a head or a light bulb. They're allowed an additional 153 sqft beyond that frame, the maximum height of a billboard structure. Notwithstanding the exceedance area, the extension area is 45ft. It must meet the principal building setback in that appropriate zoning district, all billboards must be separated by a minimum distance of 1500ft. We currently allow up to four billboard sign faces on a structure. They are allowed to be in a v formation. And we don't have a lot of language on electronic billboards, but I wanted to provide you what we have. So we do allow digital billboards. Currently they cannot change more than once every 8 seconds. Static images are and it must have no animation and the transition from one image to the next must occur in 1 second or less. Electronic display must contain a default mechanism in case of it malfunctioning to full black image or to turn off the sign within 12 hours of reported malfunction. So that's the current code regulations that we have in speaking with the council on what their concerns are and some of the concerns that we've heard from residents with the more recent billboards that were constructed as visual distraction from motorists, the visibility or nuisance of lights from residential areas, the digital sign brightness setbacks associated with the signs and the billboard heights. So some potential solutions would be, number one, I think we currently don't regulate the brightness. So that would be something that we would be able to do. We can increase separation distance for digital because they are more intense and you can see them from further away. We can increase the setback. In particular, what I find problematic c two district, so like 53rd street does not have a setback. So that can allow them to get quite close to the street. Reduce the number of zoning districts would be an option. Clearance areas. So what we've been finding to be from the complaints that we receive is when the billboards are on already heavily developed sites and they're hanging over buildings or over parking lots and things like that. So we could say, you can't have a billboard that overhangs a building or something along those lines. I wanted to provide kind of the timeline we're on. So currently, today we're at the public hearing. So this is our normal path forward. So April 16 would be, we will come with a staff recommendation to you, and then you will vote on a recommendation to council. May 1 would be the public hearing at the committee of the whole, and then the first consideration would be May 8, May 22, June 12 would be the third considerati

There are down payment assistance programs available exclusively for low to moderate income home buyers.
Home funds have been used to subsidize the construction of new homes built by Habitat for Humanity.

In a city that is 50% white and 50% everybody else, to have a 100% whites appearing only seating section for the public employees, the highest paid, most influential people, is outrageous.
The state auditor of Iowa is now conducting a re-audit of the city of Davenport.
The state auditor has issued a subpoena to the city council. The city of Davenport has responded by suing the state auditor to quash the subpoena.
Misses Merritt fully cooperated with hiding the payoffs until after the election.
Misses Merritt is under investigation for her actions as the chief financial officer.

So let us tie down the second with the chains of the constitution so the second will not become the legalized version of the first. What we've seen here week after week are criminals in our city government taking our taxpayer dollars and using it however you please. With no consideration for your constituents. Here we are today discussing another exorbitant payment. To someone who was at the table for each and every one of the deals. Or should I say arrangements. And you're discussing giving her a salary increase. To match the amount paid for the person who departed the position. Who'd been in the position for seven, eight years. What job do you have? Or can you get? When you start with the ending salary of your predecessor, make it make sense. Y'all are up here handing out money like it's growing on trees in the back of city hall. Is it? If so, tell me which tree to check for the money. I want some. Maybe we can do the streets with it. Maybe we can get these people off the streets. Anything would be better use of the money than this proposal to continue to give her anything. She's not worth it. Thank you. Next, please. Judith Lee, second ward. I appreciate very much what doctor Sidron said. And I agree. That's what we've been watching for quite a while. As I said before, the city has had six months to take care of this issue. I appreciate that many of most of the new aldermen have worked hard to create a new binding agreement. And stepped away from that MoU. It's not easy to turn this mess around even a little bit. I appreciate that. This agreement says that Miss Merritt cannot apply for the position. That's important. It'll help close an unfortunate chapter. One of my concerns is that this agreement is signed by the mayor and Miss Merritt. Once again, if you pass this, you are giving the mayor more authority than he has. It should be signed by city council. At a minimum, two thirds of city council. The mayor has no authority over either one of those positions. So the signature block itself is invalid in this. And you should not pass it without further consideration. If you pass it at all. I've got questions on the severance section seven. On the term section one, and on termination section six. Because they appear to conflict. I don't understand some of the involuntary separation things. And it says in six b. If council determines she has performed or not performed something so egregious. That she would be ousted by two thirds of a vote. But then it says she can be reinstated as CFO and assistant if you pass this. This section should also make clear. If she is removed by a two thirds vote of the council. Any lump sum payments in section seven do not apply. You've got contradictions in this thing that need to be addressed by a decent, knowledgeable, and unbiased attorney, which we are struggling with here as a city. I'm also uncomfortable with a level of familial association between her and her husband as it relates to management of the money in this city. It took almost two pages to explain how to make this work, and yet I believe it would be better if he were placed in his original position until she is no longer interim. If indeed she goes back to CFO, then you need conflict of interest agreements still between the two of them, because either way, you've got two people who are married to each other managing all the money in this city. And that is a concern to me. So not only am I concerned with what Doctor Sidron said, I'm concerned with the authority to sign this document. I'm concerned with the contents of this document, and I'm concerned that we are trying to rush something through when other entities, as well as some of you, put this city in a bind about this position and about the corporation council decision, and is now trying to force you into different ways to fix it without still fixing some of the problems. The mayor doesn't have the authority to sign this. Only you do. We've got conflicts regarding termination, and we've got conflicts of interest that aren't even addressed if she goes back to CFO. Two people control all the money in this city, and they are married to each other. I've got real concerns with this whole thing, and I request that you either don't sign it or certainly don't vote on it tonight and go back and fix it. Thank you. Thank you. Next, please. Diane Salmon, 8th board. We see that the $50,000 bonus issue has been dropped from the agenda, but hasn't really been dropped. Where do the amounts that are supposed to be retroactively paid and the amounts that is supposed to start being paid out and may come from who got to choose those amounts? It feels like this is all just a bunch of award games. Because if you retro her payback and you add in the $6,273 per month starting May 1 until the new city administrator is hired, she still ends up with well over $50,000. No one else receives that amount of pay. And some people have been working multiple positions for years. It also says under the new agreement, she would be paid $174,420, plus wage increases provided to other department heads and non bargaining employees. Does this mean we are going to see pay increases and raises for the civil rights director and her management staff. It says it's provided to other departments. So are you going to act like those positions are not as valuable as this one is? You can't pick and choose who you want to give massive amounts of money to and think that's okay. The mean girls club and the good old boys narrative needs to be stopped. And you need to stop spending the taxpayers money like it's monopoly money. That has no value, because it does. We have people going

So in December of last year, city council passed a moratorium on new billboard development within the city. The purpose of that was really to evaluate our current regulations and identify any necessary code updates. So the City of Davenport, we currently have 73 billboards scattered throughout our commercial corridors, the downtown, as well as our industrial parks. So our current billboard regulations, so currently they're only allowed in four zoning districts, two of our commercial districts, and then our light industrial and heavy industrial zoning districts. Our zoning ordinance also outlines principal use standards which regulate the location of billboards. So they are prohibited along our interstate highway. They are also prohibited in historic districts and on properties with local landmarks. And then we also regulate distance from residential neighborhoods. So if a sign is less than 300 sqft, it must be a minimum of 100ft from any residential district. And then billboards over 300 sqft must be at least 150ft from any residential district. We also regulate the sign area, so there's a maximum sign area allowance of 672 sqft, plus an extension area not to exceed 153. Then there's a maximum sign height of 45ft. Billboards are required to meet the principal building setbacks of the zoning district that they're placed in. And then there is a separation requirement between billboards with a minimum distance of 1500ft. So our code allows up to four billboard sign faces on one structure that's allowed to be in the v configuration. And then we have two standards outlining how electronic billboards are regulated. The first being that electronic billboards cannot change more than once every 8 seconds. Static images with no animation are required, and the transition from one image to the next must not occur in 1 second or less. And then the second requirement is that electronic display must contain a default mechanism to show a full black image or turn the sign off in case of a malfunction within 12 hours. So throughout this process, city staff have been trying to identify some of the deficiencies with our city code. So with the feedback from city council, the public, and the plan and zone commission last meeting, we've been able to kind of categorize the areas of concern. So that's really addressing the brightness and intensity of electronic billboards, the oversignage of our commercial corridors, visual distraction that billboards have on motorists, impacts on the character of our residential neighborhoods, their proximity to the streets, and then separation requirements between electronic billboards. insights.observation: In December of last year, city council passed a moratorium on new billboard development within the city to evaluate our current regulations and identify any necessary code updates.

City staff have been trying to identify some of the deficiencies with our city code, addressing issues such as the brightness and intensity of electronic billboards, visual distractions for motorists, impacts on the character of residential neighborhoods, proximity to streets, and separation requirements between electronic billboards.

chunks.text: the brightness and intensity of electronic billboards, the oversignage of our commercial corridors, visual distraction that billboards have on motorists, impacts on the character of our residential neighborhoods, their proximity to the streets, and then separation requirements between electronic billboards. So city staff has a draft ordinance which is printed off in front of you. So on the slide before you, we have our definition of billboard in our current code, which is shown in black. So the code defines billboard as a permanent sign directing attention to a specific business, product, service, entertainment, event, activity or other commercial activity that is not sold, produced, manufactured, furnished or conducted at the property upon which the sign is located. So staff is proposing separate regulations that apply to a static billboard and separate regulations that apply to electronic. So in order to help us define those, we've added to our definition. So static billboards in our code as proposed, would be defined as display. Static billboards display a fixed advertisement face where the face is not changeable within seconds or minutes, but where a change of face have to be re erected and affixed to the structure. So that would be your printed billboard or vinyl graphic billboard. And then electronic billboards are digital displays that can be changed within seconds or minutes by remote or automatic means. So typically that's your led or electronic computer display billboard. So there's a set of general regulations that are proposed that will apply to both static and digital, some of which are no change to our current ordinance. So we're keeping the regulation that they're prohibited along interstate highways along with billboard structures are prohibited in historic districts and adjacent to historic landmarks. A new standard is that billboards are prohibited within required landscaping areas as outlined in our landscape code. Reason for that being is we've seen some new billboard installations that are installed in required, for instance, parking lot landscape islands, or buffer yards, or landscaping that surrounds parking lots. So we want to make sure that that landscaping remains intact and this will reinforce that issue. Maximum height will remain at 45ft, and then e and f are both new standards. So creating a universal setback of 25ft from lot lines. So the c two district, there's no minimum principal building setback. So in that district, in effect, you could have a billboard placed right up to a lot line. Our c three and industrial districts have a minimum 25 foot setback. So we thought, let's make that uniform and create a little bit of distance between properties. And then f helps us regulate the separation requirements. So billboard distance separation shall be measured from the closest point of each billboard structure. This is measured in a straight line along either side of the right of way of the street. So that 1500 foot separation requirement. So if you're on the south side of 53rd street, that applies also to the north side of 53rd street. So changes to static billboard regulations. Really, we're keeping the same requirements in terms of the 15 100ft separation between static billboards. That will remain. The maximum sign face will remain at 672. With the extension area, the distance to residential district will remain at 300ft. The four billboard faces will also remain unchanged. And then the new standard standard e pertains to how they are illuminated. So that standard would be any billboard illumination shall be designed, located, shielded and directed to prevent the casting of glare or direct light upon roadways and surrounding properties, and prevent the distraction of motor vehicle operations or pedestrians in the public right away. So that's a similar requirement that we have in our sign code. So just, you know, this was a, I guess, a blind spot in your current code and how billboards are lit up at night. So then we have a set of new standards for regulating electronic billboards. So the first one being that they are prohibited in the c two corridor commercial district. This district tends to have smaller lots that are more built out. Davenport's commercial corridors are fairly well developed at this point with number of signage. So this will reduce some of the clutter on our commercial streets. We're increasing the separation requirements between digital billboards from 1500 to 3000, so we're doubling that distance. Some of the rationale there is electronic billboards are visible from further distances, given their nature of display. So this will kind of minimize the view shed as you look down a commercial street. So the maximum sign area is being reduced to 400 sqft. Electronic billboards shall be a minimum of 600ft from residential districts. So that's increased from 300 standard e up to two electronic billboard signed faces are allowed, and one billboard structure, a v arrangement, is permissible. However, no more than one electronic billboard sign face can be visible from any one street direction. So our current code would allow up to four electronic billboard signs, two facing the same way. Staff feel that that would be a visual deterrence in our community. So just limiting it to one clean static or one clean electronic display in each direction. Standard f is the same in terms of how electronic billboards change and rotate images. Standard g is the same, regulating when there's an error or malfunction that they must default to the full black image, and then f pertains to the illumination and the brightness component of electronic billboards. So that is, the maximum brightness is limited to 5000 nits when measured from the billboard's face at its maximum brightness during daytime hours, and 200 nits when measured from the billboard face at maximum brightness from dusk to dawn, the time of day between sunrise and sunset. The person involved in the construction is purchasing the land from the city at slightly above its assessed value.
The project will involve a mix of single-family homes and multi-purpose homes, promoting a mixed neighborhood.
The project will benefit from state tax credits and urban revitalization tax exemptions, which will help offset the increase in property value over time.
Community members have expressed positive sentiments about the project, anticipating it will beautify the area and restore the neighborhood.
QC Pride will hold a Unity Pride Parade with street closures in the downtown area.

insights.observation: Workers diligently continue to improve, rebuild, and maintain roadways so that motorists can safely and effectively travel.
Roadway repairs and construction work are often completed while the roadway is open to traffic, putting both motorists and workers at risk every day.
Accidents can be prevented by setting aside distractions, using extra caution, reducing speeds, and giving work zones your undivided attention while motoring.
National Work Zone Awareness Week urges all citizens to practice safe, responsible driving while traveling on roadways year-round, especially during construction season.
